newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian shares pulled higher by Lek.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian shares pulled higher by Lek.

text.p: Slovenian shares advanced for the fifth straight day on Tuesday, pulled up by drug firm Lek which was the focus of strong international demand.
The blue-chip SBI index rose 0.7 percent to 1,469.85, as turnover jumped to 532.5 million tolars from 273.1 million.
Traders forecast the SBI would reach 1,500 points by the end of the week, adding foreign buying accounted for about 60 percent of total volume.
Issue A of drug company Lek was the most actively traded stock, up 2.65 percent to 34,900 tolars on volume of 11,543 shares.
"The demand for Lek is very strong. Once the price hits 35,000 tolars it will jump to 40,000 in a matter of days," one trader said.
A second saw investor interest fanning out across the board and noted Slovenian shares were competitively priced in comparison with other stock markets in the region.

"If one compares the book value and price/earnings ratio of Slovenian firms to similar firms in the Czech Republic and Hungary, the Slovenian firms are about three times cheaper," said Alain Al Soufi, a trader at brokerage BPH.
"There is no limit to the gains if foreign demand continues," he added.
Analysts said drug makers Lek and Krka, petrol trader Petrol and trader Mercator were likely to generate the highest profits in the short-term.
Overall eight SBI shares rose, 11 fell, one was unchanged and eight were untraded.
Ordinary shares of trader Kovinotehna were the top gainers, up 8.89 percent to 490 tolars on volume of 8,350 shares.
Preferred shares of bank Hipotekarna banka Brezice were the leading decliners, down 9.12 percent to 2,999 tolars on volume of just two shares.
Petrol firmed 0.8 percent to 21,010 tolars on volume of 2,999 shares.
Krka, which is traded on the over-the-counter (OTC) market, eased 0.5 percent to 23,190 tolars in a technical correction after rising 13 percent since last Wednesday.
Mercator, another OTC share, remained unchanged at 5,400 tolars on volume of 7,260 shares.
